Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

comments: Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin Donihue
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin Donihue
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin Donihue
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin Donihue
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Excellent TA
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin Donihue
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin Donihue

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: 4. The course went a little quickly at times. For example, I would have liked more time explaining functional responses and how to transfer graphs from f(N) to N to dN/NDT and explain how density dependence altered the graphs. It took a bit of time fore me to figure all of this out. Perhaps that lecture could be split into two or done in one the lab sessions when there is more time.
Lots of work, but completely worth it.
This was an awesome class. Very difficult, but I highly recommend it for anyone who is interested in ecology.

9. A field trip, at least to Yale Myers old fields would have been so helpful. I loved all teh chalk talk but after a while it was just too much without some applicaiton. the 'lab' periods were just more of the same. the lecturing was brilliant, but a real lab period would have awesome. There is so much we could do: working hands on in R in groups, using VENSIM or other modeling software, playing with cellualr automata for spatially explicit models. sooo much that would tie it together hands on. I feel like I got so much from the lectures but really had to learn R and even the math to a certain degree "on my own" through the homework. It worked, but god it could have been easier to actually do some of that stuff together.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Understanding how ecological concepts can be tested and explored mathematically rather than simply qualitatively.

The course made me understand new concepts of modeling and also gain an appreciation for how hard it is to model ecosystem dynamics. And as hard as the assignment was, I really appreciated the history of ecology paper because I read papers that as an ecologist I probably should have already read. This course gave me a historical understanding of ecology, as well as a thorough introduction to modeling.

Interesting overview of how ecologists develop dynamical models. I now have a basic understanding of ecology as a science and what ecologists do. I am less intimidated by the mathematical models in academic literature.
The term project. It was great to learn the material, but actually applying that to a real problem was the most useful for me.
Os' teaching

Os is brilliant. Colin is so helpful. Its an incredible survey of modern ecological theory with the meat to make it worthwhile. But its very heady. Difficult to ground/too conceptual at times. For me, grounding it in simulation would have been an option, or relating it to biological or experimental reality a bit more.
Lab assignments and the final project were most helpful for learningLectures were well organized and concepts were fully explained
The subject material was very interesting and it was easy to see how information taught in the course is extremely useful in wildlife management.

Dr. Schmitz really has a talent for teaching theoretical ecology. Although I didn't learn everything I was intended to learn in the course because of time constraints, I found that I even had insights in other classes thanks of this class.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I think the overall flow of the course and helping the students maintain the big picture or important learning goals during the lectures. Often times it was unclear exactly where a lecture was headed or what the point of it was, and this was only understandable in retrospect. We also, for example, talked about ecosystem models in various places throughout the class, and the timing and purpose of these was a bit unclear.

As mentioned above, I think some lectures deserved two days worth of explanation (e.g. functional response curves, solving for equilibrium / explaining equilibrium and stable states).Additionally, I would like to see the due dates for assignments changed. 55% of our grade was saved for the last week of class (final exam, primer, and model). The primer could have been due much earlier (at the end of spring break, or the week after?), which would have allowed students to focus more on the model and final exam. I also would have liked some optional "working lab section days" where Os and Colin would both be in the classroom to aid our work on the model.

-Professor can become easily frustrated with students if they are not understanding the material. Professor seemed to get flustered if he did not know the answer to a student question--there is nothing wrong with a professor not having the answer, but it's better to acknowledge that then dismiss the student.-Occasionally the pace of the course was too fast. It felt like several students were confused/lost in some lectures.-

In the future there should be a heavier focus on isoclines, especially interpreting phase planes. A lot of the concepts could be a lot easier to grasp with an understanding of what the phase plane analysis can tell you.
Maybe have the work spread out more. The beginning of the course and the end were very heavy while the middle was light.

The learning tends to be pretty 1 way, in that Os is brilliant and downloads his brain every day the whole semester. He's definitely open to questions, but its difficult to really get a word in sometimes.The interactive aspects of the class is kind of a joke: its us trying to complete Os's sentences and him getting frustrated that we don't get it.By the end of the semester, we do get it, so I sort of trust the process, but I thinkmore space for field trip, actual labs, discussion, and processing of material would be ideal...maybe just a bit of the enormous depth and breadth of material could be cut for the sake of pedagogy.The readings were great and well organized, but almost never directly referred to in class, and so were the first thing to go when I was swamped, by this class and others. Connecting the readings more to the work and utilizing them more would be useful.
there was a lot of material and I would have preferred some clarification of what the professor believed to be most important to comprehend
A bit more explanation of specific parameters in the equations would be helpful.
A final paper, a final project, and a final test are way too many assignments to complete well.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: They seemed to complement each other well.
Lab was not particularly effective--the material in it felt like a footnote to course material and wasn't really a "lab."
Well structured.

The lab was basically an extension of class, with a few exceptions. I would love to see some actual group lab excercises where we used modeling software to visually explore the dynamics, or work on problems together.
Yes, learned a lot from the lab section and there was definite overlap and connection between lectures and lab assignments
The class lectures and the lab were really integrated seamlessly.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Colin was very open and helpful. Office hours were great. I would have been down to have him teach a class or a lab.
TA was accessible and knowledgeable of the material. I only had positive and helpful interactions with him.
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin was great. I think having taken this specific class would have helped him a bit with the details, but that's not hit fault.

Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Strengths of Colin as a TF: Colin held regular office hours, and he did a good job explaining many concepts, but as he had never taken the course before, he could not answer all of our questions. He was timely in returning homework assignments.Weaknesses of Colin as a TF: The only weakness is that Colin had never taken the course, so he wasn't always able to guide us / answer questions.

Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin was very kind, thoughtful, and willing to help. Occasionally Colin seemed unsure about some course material but he was honest and open about that, and was willing to find the answers for you.
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin is great. Knowledgeable and keen to help out with problems/ questions.
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Did a fine job
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin was really clear and extremely helpful in all his explanations.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I wanted a better understanding of modeling and how I might incorporate modeling into my research.
Elective.
Fits in very well. I wish there were more classes like this at FES

I wanted to learn modeling and i wanted to learn ecology "for real". I do feel like I got to do both. My interest is in soil ecology on the one hand (for which this was amazing) and complex systems on the other (for which this was useful, but not quite generic enough to really fulfill my need). It was very firmly grounded in actual ecosystem pattern and process, which is great for the ecological side, but detracts from the way in which it could be a more generic modeling course. It would be great to have a bit less specificity with ecosystem realism and bit more of a treatment of spatial and landscape modeling as well as the process of parametrization / model application and exploration of some models that are actually used.

I am interested in conservation science and this course was relevant because I got to learn about ecological theory that is directly applicable to conservation but is not always well-known by conservationists. I would like to have more conservation-oriented or applicable courses.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It sounded like something that would complement other courses I have taken and introduce me to new concepts in ecological modeling.
Personal interest and desire to build the skill set taught.
Applicable to my studies and future goals.
see above. i was itchy to do some math. i wanted to play in phase space.
Interested in ecological theory that is applicable to conservation and was interested in the final project assignment
Because I am interested in wildlife management and dynamics between different organisms in a system plays a large role in management.
I am interested in modeling dynamic systems, and this course seemed to cover all possible topics related to dynamic systems.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes, but see comment on phase planes above.
yes
Yes. pretty amazing learning happened. But very very hard.

Yes. Would have preferred some extra, perhaps optional, lab meetings to delve more into using R studio - I made some easy to fix mistakes in the program at first that could have been easily resolved with a more comprehensive intro to R session
Yes
Yes.
Yes - good conceptual foundation of differential equations in ecology, and writing a dynamical systems model.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: For homework assignments and studying for the exam, we formed work groups which helped tremendously in trouble-shooting problems and going over concepts.
N/A
Making group work a more structured part of this course would be a great idea.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be ready to work hard, but you will learn a lot and be a more well-rounded ecologist due to this course.

A fair amount of work--several problem sets, a very big final project, two shorter lit review papers, and a shorter final exam. The course can feel intimidating and overwhelming to those students with a limited background in ecology or math.
Expect lots of work, but a great return on the time investment.
Be preparedto work hard and study.

Buy the book. Go over your notes each day. Do the readings. Make time for the course. Take advantage of office hours. prepare questions and ask them or it will just blow by like the breeze. Very challenging and rewarding course that inflect much of my future learning. I hope I get a chance to apply this knowledge in my professional career, and feel more inclined to pursue a career in ecology due to this class. I now feel like I understand ecology from the inside instead of the outside. That said, it would be great to have a little outside time!
If youdon't understand something, ask early on, because everything builds off of everything else and it is very easy to get lost in the course.
